channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: E.U. Referendum: Britain Votes on Whether to Leave or Remain
item.description: Britain decides today whether to leave or stay in the European Union. Follow along for updates and analysis.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: The Interpreter: Making Sense of ‘Brexit’ in 4 Charts
item.media:description: Source: YouGov. This map based on YouGov’s online polling shows support for leaving or remaining in the European Union in 188 areas of the country.
item.description: To grasp why some Britons favor remaining in the European Union and others want to leave, you need to grasp some deep divisions within the country.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: A Tour of Falluja Reveals Grim Remnants of Life Under ISIS
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces looked at literature found on top of a small cage that the Islamic State used to hold prisoners in the Nazal district of Falluja, which was liberated this month.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Iraqi forces liberating the city are finding beheaded bodies, apocalyptic streetscapes and clumps of hair from fighters who shaved to blend in with fleeing civilians. Our reporter describes what he saw.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Interpreter: The State Department’s Dissent Memo on Syria: An Explanation
item.media:description: President Obama at a White House briefing on Aug. 20, 2012. It was during this briefing that Mr. Obama warned of consequences if President Bashar al-Assad of Syria crossed a “red line.”
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.description: A memo issued last week that criticizes the Obama administration’s Syria policy is written in language that can be difficult to parse. Here’s what it means.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Letter From Africa: Seeking to Define the Post-Mandela South Africa
item.media:description: Buses were set on fire and looters ransacked shops this week in the South African capital, Pretoria.
item.description: At a time of violence and political unrest, an opposition leader plays a long game against President Jacob Zuma and the African National Congress.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: German Movie Theater Attack Said to Injure Dozens
item.media:description: Police officers arrived outside a movie theater complex where an armed man reportedly opened fire on Thursday in Viernheim, Germany.
item.description: German news media said an assailant entered a theater in the western town of Viernheim, with unconfirmed accounts of at least 25 people hurt.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: FARC Rebels in Colombia Reach Cease-Fire Deal With Government
item.media:description: A FARC soldier during a trek through the jungle in March.
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.description: The FARC rebels agreed to lay down their weapons in a conflict believed to have killed more than 200,000 people over half a century.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: John Ashe, Ex-Diplomat Accused in U.N. Corruption Case, Dies at 61
item.media:description: John W. Ashe, a veteran diplomat from Antigua, served as president of the United Nations General Assembly from September 2013 until the next September.
item.description: Mr. Ashe, a former president of the General Assembly, was accused in a bribery scheme that involved more than $1 million in payments from sources in China.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Amjad Sabri, Famed Sufi Singer, Is Gunned Down in Pakistan
item.media:description: Onlookers and journalists gathering around the car driven by the singer Amjad Sabri, who was killed after unidentified gunmen fired into his car, in Karachi, Pakistan, on Wednesday.
item.description: Mr. Sabri, a prominent singer of Sufi devotional songs, had been named in a blasphemy case, and a wing of the Pakistani Taliban made an unconfirmed claim of responsibility in the killing.
item.dc:creator: ZIA ur-REHMAN and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Lightning in India Kills More Than 70, Mostly Farmworkers
item.description: Lightning strikes that punctuated the monsoon season’s inaugural heavy rains left scores of farmers and others dead in the country’s northeast.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: North Korea’s Successful Missile Test Shows Program’s Progress, Analysts Say
item.media:description: Members of the Japan Self-Defense Forces set up a missile unit to be deployed in case of a North Korean rocket launch in Tokyo on Tuesday.
item.description: The Musudan ballistic missile’s launch was a success, state media said, quoting Kim Jong-un as boasting that North Korea could strike United States forces in the Pacific.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Voting Again, Spain Faces Threat to Two-Party System
item.media:description: Supporters of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, the candidate of the conservative Popular Party, in Málaga, Spain, this week. The country will hold new elections on Sunday, the second vote in six months.
item.description: Despite cooperation in city and regional politics, parties have resisted forming coalitions after inconclusive national voting and the rise of new parties like Podemos.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Christo’s ‘Floating Piers’ to Close at Night for Repairs
item.media:description: Visitors last weekend at Christo’s “The Floating Piers,” which joins islands and the mainland on Lake Iseo, Italy. The installation runs until July 3.
item.description: The installation on Lake Iseo in Northern Italy has drawn over 350,000 visitors, wearing out the walkway’s fabric and straining local infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Sinosphere: China Vows to Replace ‘Poisonous’ Running Tracks at Schools
item.media:description: A sports field at a primary school in Beijing. The Ministry of Education has said running tracks will be inspected and, if found to contain toxic materials, replaced.
item.description: The tracks, made of industrial waste, have reportedly sickened thousands of children in a country already troubled by environmental hazards.
item.dc:creator: OWEN GUO

item.title: Hong Kong Lawmaker ‘Long Hair’ Is Arrested Over Donation
item.media:description: Leung Kwok-hung, center, a lawmaker, was a central figure in the pro-democracy Occupy Central protests that began in late 2014.
item.description: Regulators accused Mr. Leung Kwok-hung of concealing from the city’s legislature a payment of $32,000.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG and PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Rescue Flight Evacuates 2 Sick Workers From the South Pole
item.media:description: A rescue plane picking up two sick workers at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station, operated by the National Science Foundation.
item.media:credit: Robert Schwarz/National Science Foundation, via Associated Press
item.description: The plane took the patients to Chile, the National Science Foundation said, without giving details of their medical conditions.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Saudis Question U.N. Leader Over Report on Rights Violators
item.media:description: The deputy crown prince of Saudi Arabia, Mohammed bin Salman, with the secretary general of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, at the headquarters of the United Nations in New York on Wednesday. The prince arrived 45 minutes late, delaying Mr. Ban’s schedule for the rest of the day.
item.description: The United Nations secretary general had initially listed the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen among the armies accused of killing children in 2015, before taking it off.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Abortion Pill Orders Rise in 7 Latin American Nations on Zika Alert
item.media:description: Mifepristone, also known as RU 486, is a pill that induces an abortion. It is one the medications sold to Latin America women by Women on Web.
item.description: Orders rose from 36 to 76 percent in nations where the disease is causing babies to be born with tiny heads and damaged brains, a new study says.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. and PAM BELLUCK

item.title: Maharashtra State in India Grants Jews Minority Status
item.description: Maharashtra, which is home to an estimated 3,000 of India’s 4,500 Jews, approved the application for official recognition.
item.dc:creator: AYESHA VENKATARAMAN

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Debate Even Divides Cats (and Dogs) on Twitter
item.media:description: Where does Grumpy Cat fall in the debate over Britain leaving the European Union? The pets of Twitter are divided.
item.description: #CatsAgainstBrexit, #CatsForBrexit and other pet hashtags have started to appear as Twitter users inject some humor into the European Union debate.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA and CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Juchitán de Zaragoza Journal: Bathroom Debate Complicates Mexican Town’s Acceptance of a Third Gender
item.media:description: Ms. Mendez at home, altering a traditional Oaxacan shirt. Muxes dress as men or women, and tend to be feminine in their manners and the way they express themselves in the Zapotec language, experts say.
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.description: A push for transgender bathroom rights is unsettling the Zapotecs of southern Oaxaca, despite their long embrace of a third gender.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Refugee Who Walked Through Channel Tunnel Pleads Guilty but Is Freed
item.media:description: Abdul Rahman Haroun, a Sudanese refugee, braved speeding trains to walk 31 miles through the Channel Tunnel last summer.
item.description: Abdul Haroun, a Sudanese refugee, was sentenced to nine months in prison but was allowed to walk free because of the time he had already spent incarcerated.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Rory McIlroy Says He Won’t Attend Olympics Over Zika Concerns
item.media:description: “Even though the risk of infection from the Zika virus is considered low, it is a risk, nonetheless, and a risk I am unwilling to take,” the golfer Rory McIlroy said in a statement.
item.description: The decision makes the golfer one of the highest-profile athletes to withdraw over the health scare.
item.dc:creator: KAREN CROUSE

item.title: Jaguar Shot Dead After Olympic Torch Event in Brazil
item.description: The animal, who had apparently escaped a zoo enclosure, was shot after she moved toward a soldier, the military said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Rescue Flight Lands at South Pole to Evacuate Sick Worker
item.media:description: The Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station in 2002. The National Science Foundation, citing medical privacy, did not disclose the identity of the sick worker at the station or that person’s condition.
item.media:credit: David McCarthy/National Science Foundation, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The plane, which used skis to land on the snow and ice, was to remain at a station for about 10 hours, the National Science Foundation said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: What in the World: Will Ersatz Dollars Satisfy Cash-Starved Zimbabweans?
item.media:description: The old Zimbabwean dollar, which the government printed without restraint a decade ago.
item.description: Zimbabwe has been using the United States dollar as its currency, but those dollars have all but disappeared. Now the central bank is introducing replacement notes.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: What in the World: A New Verb in Mexico: Trumpear (From ‘to Punch’)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; photographs by MaraZe and Joseph Sohm/Shutterstock
item.description: Responding to remarks by Donald J. Trump, Mexicans are using satire, games, caricatures and other forms of ridicule to express anger and national pride.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: Dog Meat and Lychees: A Pairing Meant to Make You Feel Warm Inside
item.media:credit: Illustration by Antonio de Luca; Photos by Eric Isselee and Eak Moto/shutterstock
item.description: At a festival in southern China that dog lovers condemn, the food pairing is all about energy, balance and fighting heat with heat.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: It's Bad in Eritrea, but Not That Bad
item.media:description: Eritrean citizens in Switzerland protesting a recent U.N. report that accused Eritrean leaders of committing crimes against humanity.
item.description: A shrill and shoddy U.N. report about human rights abuses in Eritrea may only worsen the repression.
item.dc:creator: BRONWYN BRUTON
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The World’s Disappearing Sand
item.description: Extracting the stuff is a $70 billion industry, but it can inflict terrible costs on the environment.
item.dc:creator: VINCE BEISER

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: R.I.P., Jo Cox. May Britain Remember Your Wisdom.
item.media:description: A wall of tributes in London on Monday for Jo Cox, a member of Britain’s Parliament who was murdered last week.
item.description: A united Europe would be a fitting legacy for a woman no longer able to influence the world in other ways.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
